title: Midøya
text:
Midøya (sometimes called "Mia") is an island in <a href="Molde%20Municipality">Molde Municipality</a> in <a href="M%C3%B8re%20og%20Romsdal">Møre og Romsdal</a> county, <a href="Norway">Norway</a>. The island sits at the entrance to the <a href="Romsdalsfjorden">Romsdalsfjorden</a> between the islands of <a href="Dryna">Dryna</a> and <a href="Otr%C3%B8ya">Otrøya</a>. Until 1965, the island was divided between the municipalities of <a href="S%C3%B8r-Aukra">Sør-Aukra</a> and <a href="Vatne%20%28municipality%29">Vatne</a>. The <a href="Midsund%20Bridge">Midsund Bridge</a> connects this island to the village of <a href="Midsund%20%28village%29">Midsund</a> on the neighboring island of Otrøya.
Name.
The <a href="Old%20Norse">Old Norse</a> form of the name was "Miðja". The name is identical with the word "miðja" which means "in the middle". The island lies between the two other islands of <a href="Dryna">Dryna</a> and <a href="Otr%C3%B8ya">Otrøya</a> - but it could also refer to the fact that the island was an important border mark between the district of <a href="Sunnm%C3%B8re">Sunnmøre</a> (and the <a href="Gulating">Gulating</a> assembly) and the district of <a href="Romsdal">Romsdal</a> (and the <a href="Frostating">Frostating</a> assembly). It was mentioned as the dividing place in the historic <a href="Historia%20Norvegiae">Historia Norvegiae</a>, and it continued to be the dividing line until 1965 when the dividing line was moved upon the creation of Midsund Municipality.
